articles.title: JULY IN THE YEAR 1978
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's busy schedule for July and August 1978, featuring numerous star parties at various locations including Fremont Peak and Henry Coe Park. Key events include a planned expedition for a Lunar graze occultation of Aldebaran, Board of Directors and General Meetings, an Annual Banquet with a guest speaker, and a joint conference with WAA, AANC, ALPO, and ASP at Cal Poly University. The schedule offers a mix of observational activities, club administration, social gatherings, and educational programs for members.

articles.title: Report of June 17th General Meeting
articles.summary: This report details announcements from a June 17th General Meeting, including updates on John Rhodes' health, upcoming conferences (San Luis Obispo), plans for a lunar occultation/graze, and the July banquet where new board members will be installed. It also covers the ongoing search for a February eclipse viewing site and an inspiring program on amateur astronomy contributions. Additionally, there's a brief report on a Fremont Peak star party and an AANC board meeting where club members were nominated for an award.

articles.title: Don Machholz (356-7727)
articles.summary: The article provides an update for Northern Hemisphere amateur astronomers on two comets visible during the summer: Periodic Comet Wild 2 (1978b) and Comet Meier (1978f). Both comets are described as slowly fading or moving towards the sun/southward, making current observation opportunities limited. Details such as their constellations, magnitudes (mag. 11 and mag. 9, respectively), and physical appearance are provided.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Wild 2 (1978b)
articles.summary: This document presents ephemeris data for Periodic Comet Wild 2 (1978b), including its right ascension, declination, and estimated magnitude for various dates in June and July 1978. The information, crucial for tracking and observing the comet, is sourced from I.A.U. Circular 3177.

articles.title: Comet Meier (1978f)
articles.summary: This document provides astrometric data for Comet Meier (1978f), detailing its right ascension, declination, and visual magnitude observations from June to August 1978. Sourced from I.A.U. Circular 3227, the data illustrates the comet's changing position and increasing brightness over time, accompanied by a visual sketch of a comet's tail.

articles.title: Sky Watching at Skyline
articles.summary: Norm Wild hosted a successful star party for eight high school students at the old Skyline site on Tuesday, June 6. Despite the original site being blocked, they found an excellent viewing spot near the road. Wild recommends this area for small weeknight groups with up to four telescopes.

articles.title: The Finest Deep Sky Objects on the Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens Chart VI
articles.summary: This document provides detailed observational data and practical viewing notes for several prominent deep-sky objects featured on Chart VI of the Skalnate Pleso Atlas of the Heavens. For each object, it lists astronomical specifics such as coordinates, magnitudes, sizes, types, and distances, alongside guidance on optimal viewing conditions and recommended telescope powers. The descriptions cover a range of objects, including planetary nebulae and various galaxy types.

articles.title: Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects - Chart IV, conclusion
articles.summary: The article concludes Chart IV of "Finest Skalnate Pleso Objects," detailing observing notes for several deep-sky objects in the constellation Hercules, including the globular clusters M13 (NGC 6205) and M92 (NGC 6341), and the planetary nebula NGC 6210, offering descriptions and viewing tips. It also includes an update on the chosen site for the July 2 Aldebaran graze event.

articles.title: Pre-registration
articles.summary: This document is an urgent call for observers to pre-register for an upcoming graze of Aldebaran, stressing the need for more participants by June 30th. It highlights the rarity of this specific event in the area, being the only one in the current 4-year cycle, followed by a 14-year wait. Even without pre-registration, observers are encouraged to attend as extra stations will be available.

articles.title: Special person needed!!!!!
articles.summary: A volunteer is sought for an astronomical observation event to cover a single mountain station south of the main path, which will involve fewer timings than other stations. The event is located 2.5 miles north of Clay, California, and specific directions, meeting points, and times for a convoy are provided for Saturday evening and Sunday morning. This less busy station is suggested as potentially ideal for a first-time observer.

articles.title: First-time jitters
articles.summary: This article addresses first-time participants in an observational event, aiming to alleviate "jitters" by offering reassurance, practical guidance, and helpful resources. It outlines necessary equipment like telescopes or binoculars and tape recorders, and clarifies optional items, while also welcoming those who wish to observe without making official timings.

articles.title: Additional Ravings
articles.summary: This document discusses upcoming astronomical observations, noting that the presence of the sun will simplify data reduction by allowing all events to be considered dark limb. It highlights that the star's finite diameter (0.02") will result in non-instantaneous events, lasting up to a second, offering a unique opportunity to observe the physical size of stars with standard telescopes.

articles.title: An Astrophotography Trip To Arizona
articles.summary: Bob Finnquist and Jean Petersen embarked on an astrophotography trip to Arizona, motivated by a desire to photograph Omega Centauri. After extensively preparing their modified Celestron telescopes and renting a motor home, they located a dark desert site near Sasabe with assistance from a local amateur astronomer. Despite encountering a herd of bulls, they successfully photographed Omega Centauri and several other deep-sky objects during their five nights in the Sonoran Desert.

articles.title: Blurbs
articles.summary: The article provides several club updates, including an overdue reminder for membership renewals and the election of new club officers, who will be installed at an upcoming banquet. It also highlights a forthcoming February solar eclipse and encourages members to participate in Graze Occultations for scientific contribution and fun. Additionally, the Bulletin budget was increased due to higher postage costs.

articles.title: Recent Observations of the Rings of Uranus
articles.summary: Recent observations of Uranus's rings in December 1977 and April 1978, conducted at 2-micron infrared wavelength, led to the discovery of four additional rings, bringing the total to nine. These observations confirmed that some rings, particularly the widest 'epsilon' ring, are elliptical. Direct infrared detection with the 200-inch telescope, combined with failed attempts in visible light, suggests the rings are composed of much darker material than Saturn's.

articles.title: Cathy Pinheiro
articles.summary: Cathy Pinheiro, the club librarian, announces the initiation of a monthly listing of available books and magazines from the club's library, encouraging members to utilize this resource. The document also includes an announcement for the club's annual meeting to be held on July 16th at Michael's restaurant, detailing the buffet cost, reservation requirements, and contact information.

articles.title: Dennis Frarichs-Medlock
articles.summary: The article describes a particularly large and energetic astronomy star party at Big Bear, featuring over 600 attendees and nearly 200 telescopes, with a strong presence from Bay Area groups like SJAA and Chabot. Notable moments included media coverage by KPBS, Paul Zubrowski receiving a significant award for his amateur astronomy work, and various social activities and observations despite challenging weather conditions. Participants generally enjoyed the event and are already anticipating next year's gathering.

articles.title: A WORD PUZZLE by Don Machholz
articles.summary: This article, titled "A WORD PUZZLE by Don Machholz," presents a classic word search puzzle. It challenges readers to find names of planets, dwarf planets, asteroids, and zodiac constellations hidden in various directions within a grid of letters.
